content.body: wow this srcset/<picture> thread got huge

for those discussing it previously: the CG FSA copyright license is non-exclusive (so presumably authors should be allowed to multi-license if they care to) and also identical to the OWFA copyright license (thus not really an instance of license proliferation)
it is also pretty much maximally permissive afaict, only requires attribution

tantek: one thing I'm curious about (maybe to be covered in your blog post) - how is it possible to multi-license with CC0, since CC0 places a work in the public domain and therefore presumably makes it not copyrighted and not subject to a copyright license?
I'm not a copyright expert so it's not clear to me if this is a genuine contradiction or not
any firefox mobile peeps around?

othermaciej, if you read the text of CC0, it's really just an irrevocable royalty-free license to use the work however one pleases.  So it's trivially compatible with any other license, in the sense that all other licenses are redundant, IIUC.

Personally I have no problem with requiring attribution, but IANAL and don't know if the CG copyright license is actually compatible with other standard permissive licenses, so I'd prefer to keep CC0 in addition to be safe until I get clarification from lawyers.
Preferably approval by the FSF or OSI.
AryehGregor: I read it - it claims to abandon copyright and place the word in the public domain

"To the greatest extent permitted by, but not in contravention of, applicable law, Affirmer hereby overtly, fully, permanently, irrevocably and unconditionally waives, abandons, and surrenders all of Affirmer's Copyright and Related Rights and associated claims and causes of action..."
it seems like if you surrender all copyright, you can't also grant a copyright license to the same work
but again, this may be a naive and uninformed understanding

Ah, I see.  You also have this: "Should any part of the Waiver for any reason be judged legally invalid or ineffective under applicable law, then the Waiver shall be preserved to the maximum extent permitted taking into account Affirmer's express Statement of Purpose. In addition, to the extent the Waiver is so judged Affirmer hereby grants to each affected person a royalty-free, non transferable, non sublicensable, non exclusive, irrevocable
and unconditional license . . ."

Ah, I see.  You also have this: "Should any part of the Waiver for any reason be judged legally invalid or ineffective under applicable law, then the Waiver shall be preserved to the maximum extent permitted taking into account Affirmer's express Statement of Purpose. In addition, to the extent the Waiver is so judged Affirmer hereby grants to each affected person a royalty-free, non transferable, non sublicensable, non exclusive, irrevocable
and unconditional license . . ."
yes, in jurisdictions where it is impossible to abandon copyright and place a work in the public domain, it is instead a permissive license
but holding copyright is, by my understanding, a status that is jurisdiction-by-jurisdiction
In any event, it is accurate to say that any work licensed under CC0 can also be used under the terms of X, where X is any license whatsoever.
FSF does not seem to have examined the OWFA FSA or the W3C CG FSA

Which is the idea of multi-licensing, right?  If I release a GPL work that includes some BSD content, I can accurately say that the work is GPL-licensed, because the whole work can be used under the terms of the GPL.
I don't understand how it is possible to grant a copyright license to a work in the public domain
since I am not a lawyer, I cannot do more than (a) notice my confusion; and (b) consult an attorney
If it's actually in the public domain, then I'd think you can't "grant" a license, no.
But it doesn't really matter.  If the work is marked as CC0, then any additional licenses are redundant and therefore harmless.
what I would expect is that they are not only redundant but ineffective
but of course public domain grants you all the rights that any possible copyright license would
What would it mean for it be "ineffective"?
I mean that you can't grant a copyright license to a work not under copyright, as I understand it

Right, doing so makes no sense, but is also harmless.  I mean, I could write a piece of paper that says "I hereby grant othermaciej the right to vote in United States presidential elections" and give it to you.  It would be stupid, and not technically correct, but in the end it makes no difference to anything.

othermaciej - exactly don't bother reasoning about it since you're not a lawyer. I've asked our (Mozilla's) lawyers and according to them, yes, it is totally fine for a CG to require contributors agree to all three (CC0, OWFa, CG CLA), and then multilicense specs accordingly.
no conflicts, and such multilicensing is compatible and preferable.
Do they have an opinion on whether the CG CLA is GPL-compatible?
Or BSD-compatible, for that matter?
I didn't ask them to evaluate that
we do know that CC0 is GPL and BSD compatible however.
Yes, trivially.
Which is why I told Ian Jacobs that I'd prefer to keep the editing spec CC0-licensed to make sure that it's GPL-compatible until I have confirmation from a lawyer that it's not an issue.
It can definitely be useful to copy-paste spec text into source code comments.
agreed.
Frankly I don't think Ian Jacobs has any right to privately ask for CC0 multilicensing to be removed from CG specs.
I just declined.

I've already posed the recommendations/questions in my blog post of many months ago, and am still waiting for answers. Until policies are officially clarified with URLs on w3.org, I think the right thing to do is to keep the CC0 and OWFa multilicensing on there.

BTW to be clear - I've raised the issue, and my (and Mozilla's) recommendation of using multilicensing on CG specs directly to the AB at their f2f meeting a few months ago in San Mateo (I was a one-time invited expert to the meeting). I didn't get *any* negative feedback about that course of action.
My editing spec was CC0-licensed before it moved to a CG, and no one objected to that at any point.
AryehGregor, same with Fullscreen.
tantek: my plan is to ask Apple's in-house counsel since this does not appear to be an issue that can be evaluated intuitively
I do think CG spec contributors should be allowed to multi-license in whatever way they choose
not sure why the w3c would say otherwise, and it seems against the spirit of CGs to refuse

I don't personally have a problem with anyone who wants to using CC0 but I do not think I'd push for it or use it myself, as it's not clear to me that removing the attribution requirement is worth the extra license complexity
I don't have a problem with the attribution requirement, I have a problem with using a license that's not widely recognized.
I'd be fine with BSD.
thinks it was a mistake that CC killed the license variants that didn't require attribution
CC0 doesn't require attribution.  :)
CC0 doesn't require attribution.  :)
now there are workarounds like "you can attribute the wiki instead of individuals"
AryehGregor: CC0 - The best CC license. :-)
I'm saddened that the i18n group is filing bugs asking for complexity without use cases
e.g. asking for non-ISO weeks
why bother if people in non-ISO-week countries don't actually use week numbers on forms
Who uses week numbers on forms at all?
AryehGregor: the rationale was "European business"
AryehGregor: Personally, I've spoken about week numbers in "European business" setting but haven't seen them on a Web form ever, IIRC
anyway, non-ISO weeks are so crazy that IMO we shouldn't support them even if it means that we need to drop ISO week out of "fairness" or something
I use week numbers all the time. But not <input type='week'>.
is unhappy about the mismatch of the usage of the word "weekend" in the U.S. and the start day of the week in calendars that are laid out one week per row
even more unhappy that Ubuntu in en-US *language* does not have a pref for making weeks start on Monday in the calendar that pops out if you click the menubar clock
is generally unhappy about the coupling of en-US language and calendar stuff in software
hsivonen: just checked and kubuntu doesn't seem to have that option either, although i also can't say it bothers me that much
hsivonen, the most common convention in the US is that calendars are laid out one week per row with Sunday as the first day.
Oh, that's your point.
AryehGregor: right.
In Israel, the weekend is Friday/Saturday, so we're good.  :)
(historically Saturday was the seventh day according to everyone, AFAIK, but I guess lately no one cares about the religious significance outside of Israel)
haven't tested this but http://tuxtweaks.com/2008/12/change-the-week-start-day-in-ubuntu/
charlvn: thanks. though I wonder if that breaks when software is updated or something
for some reason, Ubuntu has an English - Denmark locale. Maybe that would make the calendar ISO-compliant while using untranslated UI strings
is unhappy about week numbers.
Why?
Because they don't really make any sense (see: confusion about zero-point) and I never know which week it is. It always seems less ambiguous to use dates
(week numbers are never used in the UK. This may affect my bias)
they never make sense unless both parties of the communication are looking at a calendar that renders week numbers *and uses Standard ISO week numbers*
example of FAIL: hotel in Portugal using ad hoc week numbers and expecting guests from parts of Europe where people expect ISO weeks to be the standard EU-wide
jgraham: They make perfect sense in countries where they are actually used. (c:
I live in a country where they are actually used and it just means that I am permanently confused
Or, at least, unable to work out when things are happening
do ISO weeks start on Monday?
othermaciej: yes
Week numbers are also never used in the US.
is that the way calendars are usually laid out in Europe? (it's been a while since I've seen a non-American calendar)
(that I've ever seen)
I've certainly not seen week numbers used for anything
Android lays out weeks starting with Monday.  It annoys me slightly.  Especially since I actually live in the one country where the workweek starts on Sunday.  :)
othermaciej: at least over here (Finland), calendars are laid out with Monday in the first weekday column and Sunday in the last weekday column
(typically with the *ISO* week number as the first column to the left of the Monday column)
AryehGregor: so you've moved from New York to Israel?
hsivonen, yes.
Currently Jerusalem.
given the way week numbers are used in europe, would it be plausible to input one in a Web form, even if it is not usually done>
othermaciej: I suppose it's *plausible*, since people do agree to do stuff on week N.
Yeah, although the idea of it horrifies me :)
Yeah, although the idea of it horrifies me :)
Here's a Scandinavian calendar: http://www.timeanddate.no/kalender/
whoa. Norway and Denmark take the Monday off for Pentecost
annevk, Ms2ger, Hixie: Now that cloning a node has moved out of the HTML spec, dealing with the "already started" flag can't be traced from the cloning algorithm
so basically you have to know what to look for in order to know what the cloning steps need to do to find additional normative statements beyond DOM Core
Oh, that sounds extremely bad
it has been argued HTML and DOM should be the same spec
but I'm not sure if that's better
the normative reference crowd would not be pleased
hsivonen: we can probably add a note under it that points to HTML
hsivonen: if you think that works please file a bug
jgraham: "extremely"
jgraham: it's just a search in some other platform specs that deal with nodes, there's not that many
annevk: ok. I'll file a bug
annevk: The expectation that people implementing any feature should do a full search of specs other than the one that defines the feature is unreasonable and will lead to problems
it kind of depends on how you implement and define the feature really, it's quite clear here that there are other requirements elsewhere
but I guess that's a fine argument to make against modularization
filed https://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=17044
The DOM spec should create a hook for the HTML spec to alert readers that it's an extension point, probably, or something like that.
With a note pointing to HTML.
(or we should just have mutual normative dependency, but . . .)
it has a hook for more than HTML
since it's prolly needed by SVG too
and the shadow stuff I guess
although maybe the shadow stuff should move into DOM
Ah, I see, it does have a hook.

so if we want to expand FormData, how exactly should we go about that
setting it on <form> could be done, but you cannot currently populate it from the server
although I guess if we define multipart/form-data better that would be doable
you cannot really do FormData[field] = value
because you can have multiple fields with the same name
and some values have both a value and a name
although I guess we could always make those File's
http://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/FormData
proposed extensions to FormData XMLHttpRequest and HTMLFormElement
does Opera have a place where they put idls they use for producing interfaces that go into their releases/
benvie: we don't do IDL
mm ok, to rephrase
is there a place that has a description of the DOM interfaces that Opera provides to javascript, preferably in a format that facilitates machine generation?
(this being for use in javascript code itself, not externally)
maybe http://caniuse.com/ has something like that? I don't think we produce it
I'm trying to expand the work I've done here to also automatically describe differences between implementations: https://github.com/Benvie/idl-for-javascript
right now it just produces spec based json but it's only a bit more work to also describe the differences as well
cool project
can't you just get the data for Opera by running the existing data you have through it?
I guess that does not give you proprietary extensions unique to Opera...
but I don't think we have many of those
yeah that's where I'm going next, generating difs based on given json description vs. what the browser shows
no bugs when parsing the IDL from the specifications?
there's a small handful of things the parser breaks at, but in all instances I've commented those out and then put the changed version that parses correctly on the next line
it's mostly some very new things
like in DOM4 for operations, the "default value" syntax has been used which the parser doesn't hndlr
`optional NodeFilter? filter = null` which I replace with `optional NodeFilter? filter`
k
I'm asking as I don't run the IDL through an actual checker so they may very well have bugs
yeah, and I'm sure with some of them there are. Many of the newer ones are generated directly in the browser by me since no official IDL exists
basically like `[].map.call(document.querySelectorAll('.idl'), function(node){ return node.textContent }).join('\n')`
but it works surprisingly well
what are we missing IDL definitions for?
let me pull up my "thing which breaks all things" and look, one moment

ok it's breaking too many things. Anyway, the goal wasn't primarily for that purpose. Anything that implements the specifications should be fine. It's just that IDL has been primarily used to describe both the specifications as well as the implementation differences.

ok it's breaking too many things. Anyway, the goal wasn't primarily for that purpose. Anything that implements the specifications should be fine. It's just that IDL has been primarily used to describe both the specifications as well as the implementation differences.
sorry about the ambiguous "we"; I meant what features have you covered that are not covered in any standard
oh, none. The purpose is to simply translate idls provided directly by w3c and whatwg as json
not to invent anything new
oh, then I do not understand what you meant by "Many of the newer ones are generated directly in the browser by me since no official IDL exists"

I was looking into the possibility of using the provided "official" idls from those sources as well as specs available from, for example, webkit's WebKit/WebCore/Source and mozilla's mozilla-central/dom
to automatically generate the differences in actual implementation
because the idls in those places to actually show pretty accurate where the differences are
so I wanted to see try and include that perspective from as many major vendors as I could while I work on this
there's way too many to do it manually
(interfaces)

it says that both mark and Mark_Vic_ are ambiguous for either mark
it isn't terrible, but it isn't ideal either
basically it has two passes, and for ambiguous speakers, if a person is taken in the first pass, they're not considered as candidates in the second pass
but the logic for handling people w/ first+last names isn't wonderful, and it doesn't handle all the magical ways people munge their names :/

hsivonen, jgraham, I don't particular care for ISO-week numbers either, nor for odd EU non-ISO-week numbers. They're both poorly designed. I prefer ordinal dates (2012-135) and different weeks altogether: http://newcal.org

othermaciej, from my understanding talking to lawyers, CC0 is basically a more internalized / international-aware version of the MIT license. If you're going to ask your lawyers anyway, please consider asking them if CC0 is close enough to MIT that you can use either or both (since apparently you can already use MIT).

And for those that have looked, the W3C CG CLA is basically a W3C-specific version of OWFa (same lawyer(s) worked on both). I'm annoyed that W3C didn't just use the standard OWFa by reference. Creating yet another bespoke license doesn't benefit anyone (see Hixie's point about license proliferation etc.).
tantek: MIT requires acknowledgment
tantek: because of "Copyright (c) <year> <copyright holders>"
tantek: which you are required to include in redistribution
tantek: CC0 has no such thing, especially in countries that acknowledge Public Domain
tantek: CC0 has no such thing, especially in countries that acknowledge Public Domain
annevk - in practice I see no reason for such explicit attribution requirements in standards. In practice when using a standard people link to it which IMHO is sufficient.
I agree that standards should be Public Domain
see http://annevankesteren.nl/2012/02/standards-red-pill

I know it is in the spec, but according to https://jwatt.org/svg/authoring/#doctype-declaration discourages this

Doctype isnt' required for XML - it's just useless noise for SVG.

Start your doc with <svg xmlns="whatever the ns is" viewBox="0 0 foo bar"> and you're golden.
the xmlns= is pretty stupid
Correct!

jarek: I have no idea if standalone viewers care, but if you're doing something for the web, *all* you need is the xmlns on the <svg> root.

I think I agree with ap's position in this case, it doesn't seem that he expressed his position in a jerky way, and it's not clear why the spec should trump WebKit and IE behavior
Support Existing Content principle should trump "editors think this other way is more elegant"
if editors don't agree with that, then it seems fine for implementations to ignore the spec on that point
so in WebKit all arguments were already optional
including for e.g. createNodeIterator
where the NodeFilter constant argument defaulted to 0 because that's what undefined got turned into
which incidentally makes it useless
in any event, I don't disagree with "Support Existing Content" but we generally do not follow that principle if browsers disagree wildly
if there's specific cases where changing the default has been shown to create minimal compat risk, and the win to changing it is large, then it seems reasonable to change
it doesn't seem like either of those conditions has been established in this case
I think supporting WebKit-specific content and Trident-specific content still trumps "this other way is more elegant"

If you set @width and @height, sending a 32dpi versus a 192dpi image is identical, except that one has more detail.
Velmont: It doesn't change the ratio. You might misunderstand what the w/h numbers are doing.

zewt: Fetching two images? No, I was only talking about actually fetching one that will fit both portrait and landscape. So if you're in portrait, you overestimate, and pick a slightly bigger picture that'll also use all your pixels in landscape. Hence you only need to fetch that image once, in case the user switches to landscape.
zewt: So you are actually hindering an extra image fetch here.
zewt: I should've written "UA wants to fetch _one_ image that it is big enough to use in both portrait and landscape".
